<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/facebook-extends-president-trumps-ban-two-years?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Facebook Hits the Snooze Button on Trump
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/facebook-extends-president-trumps-ban-two-years" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Trump banned from Facebook" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MzQ3L3RydW1wX2Jhbm5lZF9mcm9tX2ZhY2Vib29rLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The company is giving Trump’s Facebook and Instagram accounts plenty of time to catch up on beauty sleep: two more years.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook said yesterday that the former president <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/04/facebook-says-donald-trump-to-remain-banned-from-platform-for-2-years-effective-from-jan-7.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">won’t be allowed</a> back onto its social platforms until at least January 2023 (notably after the 2022 midterm elections), when it will decide whether he still presents “a serious risk to public safety.” </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">ICYMI:</strong></span><span> Following the storming of the Capitol on January 6, Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat, and Twitch all indefinitely banned Trump from their platforms.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In addition to extending Trump’s ban, Facebook also took a side on an argument that’s been ruining family dinners for months: “Should politicians get special treatment on social media?” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To make a long story short, Facebook said “no.” To make a long story longer...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook had kept a <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/3/22474738/facebook-ending-political-figure-exemption-moderation-policy?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">special list</a> of politicians who were allowed to bend its content moderation rules because their opinions were considered “newsworthy content that should, as a general rule, be seen and heard,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg said in 2019.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a U-turn, Facebook now says that any user—Trump, the Dalai Lama, your third cousin who thinks Zuck is a lizard person—could be booted for violations like bullying.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Why not go somewhere else then?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, Trump built it and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/06/02/trump-blog-dead/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">they didn’t come</a>. The independent blog Trump launched last month failed to reach even a fraction of the combined 57 million followers he still has on Instagram and Facebook—it averaged just 4,000 interactions per day, according to BuzzSumo data. Earlier this week, the blog was taken down.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Trump’s blog’s failure is a reminder that social platforms like Facebook don’t just offer a place to share snarky opinions, but also an algorithm-amplified megaphone. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But who should control that megaphone? It depends on where you live. The Nigerian government, for instance, <a href="https://www.axios.com/twitter-nigeria-president-account-f2228f1f-a269-46c9-b028-ce1bf3903bf4.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">temporarily suspended</a> Twitter Wednesday after the platform froze President Muhammadu Buhari’s account for 12 hours, saying a tweet of his violated its "abusive behavior" policy.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/may-jobs-report-offers-wins-losses-hope?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
May Jobs Report Earns Participation Trophy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The May jobs report <a href="https://www.axios.com/may-jobs-report-c1e0733e-58bd-4634-b3e2-fbb0486c4b6c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released</a> yesterday was a lot like DiGiorno pizza: perfectly OK to digest cold on a Friday morning, but you could do better. The US added 559,000 new jobs last month, compared to economists’ expectations of 670,000.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What it means:</strong> Compared to April’s dismal report, May's numbers showed that the road to the labor market’s recovery is looking more “There's a light at the end of the tunnel” than “Is this a tunnel or did I fall into a black hole?” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The big wins:</strong> The unemployment rate dropped to 5.8%, falling more than expected and hitting a new pandemic low. The number of workers who claimed unemployment because their employer lost business or closed due to the pandemic dropped by 1.5 million.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The biggest job gains were in the leisure and hospitality sector, which added 292,000 new jobs, more than the 278,000 jobs the economy added in total in April. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>While some sectors of the economy have rebounded and catapulted past their pre-pandemic levels, the job market is taking <a href="https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/biden-calls-latest-jobs-report-great-news-claims/story?id=78084482" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">longer to recover</a>. There are still 7.6 million fewer people employed in the US than before the pandemic.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
M&A
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/bill-ackmans-proposed-spac-deal-confuses-just-everyone?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Please, Mister Spacman
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Bill Ackman Short selling" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NTg3L2JpbGxfYWNrbWFuX3Nob3J0X3NlbGxpbmcuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As if SPACs weren’t confusing enough, investor Bill Ackman confirmed that he’s <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/04/business/dealbook/ackman-spac-universal.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">discussing a complex transaction</a> not worth trying to understand if you haven’t had three coffees already. But it’s a big deal, literally: If signed, it’ll be the biggest deal involving a SPAC ever.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Assuming you’ve got a cold brew close by, <a href="https://www.axios.com/ackman-pershing-square-vivendi-unversial-music-talks-25b671fa-6d32-4935-8196-350eba2e6c37.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here’s what’s going on</a>: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Last year Ackman created a SPAC, aka a “blank-check company,” called Pershing Square Tontine Holdings, which raised about $4 billion. </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Now, Pershing Square Tontine Holdings is in talks to acquire 10% of Universal Music Group (UMG), the label home to artists like Taylor Swift.  </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you’re thinking, “That’s not what SPACs are meant to do,” you’re right. Ackman is ripping up the traditional playbook of using a blank-check company to acquire a private company then take it public. Instead, through this investment, Ackman’s locking in a price for his investors when UMG lists its shares publicly, which it plans to do later this year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There’s even more <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-06-04/bill-ackman-s-spac-will-be-three-spacs?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">4D financial chess</a> going on behind the scenes, but the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/ackmans-spac-deal-to-end-all-spacs-11622818252?mod=hp_featst_pos3" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bottom line</a> is that shares in Ackman’s SPAC plummeted yesterday following the announcement, meaning investors doubt Ackman can pull off these business theatrics. </p>

</a><span>  </span>

</h3>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You don’t need one to start investing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yeah, you probably shouldn’t mention it to your vest-wearing pals who spent years earning econ degrees, but it turns out that if you <a href="https://www.fool.com/ecap/stock-advisor/sa-5-stocks-under-50-mil/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=5stocksunder50-mil&aid=9394&paid=9394&waid=9394&source=esamnbwdg0210180&psource=esamnbwdg0210180&wsource=esamnbwdg0210180&testId=e-sa-5-stocks-under-50-mil&cellId=0&campaign=sa-5-stocks-free" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">subscribe to The Motley Fool Stock Advisor</a>, they’ll just...tell you which stocks are looking good to them.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Right now, The Motley Fool is giving peeps a sneak peek behind the Stock Advisor curtain: Here’s a free <a href="https://www.fool.com/ecap/stock-advisor/sa-5-stocks-under-50-mil/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=5stocksunder50-mil&aid=9394&paid=9394&waid=9394&source=esamnbwdg0210180&psource=esamnbwdg0210180&wsource=esamnbwdg0210180&testId=e-sa-5-stocks-under-50-mil&cellId=0&campaign=sa-5-stocks-free" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">5 Stocks Under $50 Report</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Normally, you’d have to be a member of Stock Advisor to get this sort of info—but not today, reader. Today, you get those sweet, sweet stock picks for free. Tasty!</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Stop reading this and get your paws on these <a href="https://www.fool.com/ecap/stock-advisor/sa-5-stocks-under-50-mil/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=5stocksunder50-mil&aid=9394&paid=9394&waid=9394&source=esamnbwdg0210180&psource=esamnbwdg0210180&wsource=esamnbwdg0210180&testId=e-sa-5-stocks-under-50-mil&cellId=0&campaign=sa-5-stocks-free" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">five affordable stock picks</a>.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/key-performance-indicators-june-5?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Every single corporate board in the S&P 500 now has <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-04/after-pressure-all-male-boards-have-now-vanished-from-s-p-500?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">at least one woman</a> on it after Monolithic Power Systems added a female director last month, according to Bloomberg. The share of female directors at S&P companies is currently 29.7%.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“We need some divine intervention.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Utah Gov. Spencer Cox asked residents of all faiths to <a href="https://www.axios.com/gov-cox-utah-pray-rain-record-drought-2ed5be3d-1a96-463f-bc4b-9f5133c186f0.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pray for rain</a> over the weekend amid a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/03/california-drought-cause-wideranging-industry-problems?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">brutal drought</a> striking the West. “We need more rain, and we need it now." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Watch: </strong>It’s that time of year...rewatch David Foster Wallace’s commencement speech at Kenyon College in 2005. (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8CrOL-ydFMI" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">YouTube</a>)</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/calm-app-sweetgreen-others-rush-back-naomi-osakas-decision-leave-french-open?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brands Have Changed, They’re Different Now, They Swear
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/06/04/calm-app-sweetgreen-others-rush-back-naomi-osakas-decision-leave-french-open" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Naomi Osaka" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MzUwL25hb21pX29zYWthLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Tim Clayton - Corbis/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sweetgreen, Nike, Calm, and other brands moved quickly this week to <a href="https://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/naomi-osaka-french-open-brands-support-nike-1234833428/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">back</a> tennis star Naomi Osaka after she dropped out of this year’s French Open. Their moves are a reminder that on some social issues in 2021, companies no longer want to stay neutral.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> Last Sunday, Osaka <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/31/naomi-osaka-highestearning-female-athlete-world-drops-french-open?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dropped out</a> of the tournament to focus on her mental health after initially declaring she’d skip mandatory press conferences.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Osaka sponsors Sweetgreen, Nike, BareMinerals, and watchmaker Tag Heuer all issued public statements in support of her decision.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Calm, an app that produces guided meditations, </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/calm/status/1400224962544234500?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">offered</a></span><span> to pay the $15,000 fine for any player opting out of 2021 Grand Slam media appearances for mental health reasons.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At 23, Osaka has earned $55 million in the last 12 months from endorsements, putting her in a tie with Tiger Woods as the twelfth highest-paid athlete in the world. And her outspokenness stands in contrast to many athletes with high-dollar endorsement deals who have stayed quiet in the past. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Brands want to be seen as taking mental health concerns seriously, and Osaka gives them an opportunity to rally around the cause.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brewnited States of America
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Morning Brew is a lot more than just this newsletter. Here are some of our favorite pieces of content from around the Brewniverse this week…</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><em>Founder’s Journal</em></strong><strong style="color:#000">: </strong>In <a href="https://open.spotify.com/episode/3KTRqN2724twg2m28O9ArP?si=H9JpcJKbRjWRNE1wUKkOYg" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this podcast episode</a>, our cofounder Alex Lieberman explains why he bought bitcoin.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What is Amazon’s palm payments system actually like</strong>? Retail Brew’s Halie LeSavage <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2021/06/03/tested-amazon-one-amazons-palm-payments-system?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tried it out</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Facial recognition ban: </strong>Emerging Tech Brew’s Hayden Field talked to a US Senator who said he’ll introduce legislation to <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2021/06/04/federal-facial-recognition-ban-reintroduced-soon-sen-jeff-merkley-says?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ban facial recognition tech</a> until better regulations are put in place.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Twitter’s been busy: </strong>Our video guy Dan Toomey imagined what <a href="https://twitter.com/MorningBrew/status/1400918989652516875?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Jack Dorsey’s reaction</a> would be if he returned from a 12-year meditation retreat to encounter his company’s new features. </p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eICYMI:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Following the storming of the Capitol on January 6, Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat, and Twitch all indefinitely banned Trump from their platforms.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn addition to extending Trump’s ban, Facebook also took a side on an argument that’s been ruining family dinners for months: “Should politicians get special treatment on social media?” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo make a long story short, Facebook said “no.” To make a long story longer...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFacebook had kept a \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/3/22474738/facebook-ending-political-figure-exemption-moderation-policy?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003especial list\u003c/a\u003e of politicians who were allowed to bend its content moderation rules because their opinions were considered “newsworthy content that should, as a general rule, be seen and heard,” Facebook VP of Global Affairs Nick Clegg said in 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a U-turn, Facebook now says that any user—Trump, the Dalai Lama, your third cousin who thinks Zuck is a lizard person—could be booted for violations like bullying.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhy not go somewhere else then?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWell, Trump built it and \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/06/02/trump-blog-dead/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethey didn’t come\u003c/a\u003e. The independent blog Trump launched last month failed to reach even a fraction of the combined 57 million followers he still has on Instagram and Facebook—it averaged just 4,000 interactions per day, according to BuzzSumo data. Earlier this week, the blog was taken down.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eTrump’s blog’s failure is a reminder that social platforms like Facebook don’t just offer a place to share snarky opinions, but also an algorithm-amplified megaphone. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut who should control that megaphone? It depends on where you live. The Nigerian government, for instance, \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/twitter-nigeria-president-account-f2228f1f-a269-46c9-b028-ce1bf3903bf4.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etemporarily suspended\u003c/a\u003e Twitter Wednesday after the platform froze President Muhammadu Buhari’s account for 12 hours, saying a tweet of his violated its \"abusive behavior\" policy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe May jobs report \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/may-jobs-report-c1e0733e-58bd-4634-b3e2-fbb0486c4b6c.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased\u003c/a\u003e yesterday was a lot like DiGiorno pizza: perfectly OK to digest cold on a Friday morning, but you could do better. The US added 559,000 new jobs last month, compared to economists’ expectations of 670,000.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat it means:\u003c/strong\u003e Compared to April’s dismal report, May's numbers showed that the road to the labor market’s recovery is looking more “There's a light at the end of the tunnel” than “Is this a tunnel or did I fall into a black hole?” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe big wins:\u003c/strong\u003e The unemployment rate dropped to 5.8%, falling more than expected and hitting a new pandemic low. The number of workers who claimed unemployment because their employer lost business or closed due to the pandemic dropped by 1.5 million.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe biggest job gains were in the leisure and hospitality sector, which added 292,000 new jobs, more than the 278,000 jobs the economy added in total in April. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile some sectors of the economy have rebounded and catapulted past their pre-pandemic levels, the job market is taking \u003ca href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/biden-calls-latest-jobs-report-great-news-claims/story?id=78084482\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elonger to recover\u003c/a\u003e. There are still 7.6 million fewer people employed in the US than before the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs if SPACs weren’t confusing enough, investor Bill Ackman confirmed that he’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/04/business/dealbook/ackman-spac-universal.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ediscussing a complex transaction\u003c/a\u003e not worth trying to understand if you haven’t had three coffees already. But it’s a big deal, literally: If signed, it’ll be the biggest deal involving a SPAC ever.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAssuming you’ve got a cold brew close by, \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/ackman-pershing-square-vivendi-unversial-music-talks-25b671fa-6d32-4935-8196-350eba2e6c37.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehere’s what’s going on\u003c/a\u003e: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eLast year Ackman created a SPAC, aka a “blank-check company,” called Pershing Square Tontine Holdings, which raised about $4 billion. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNow, Pershing Square Tontine Holdings is in talks to acquire 10% of Universal Music Group (UMG), the label home to artists like Taylor Swift.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you’re thinking, “That’s not what SPACs are meant to do,” you’re right. Ackman is ripping up the traditional playbook of using a blank-check company to acquire a private company then take it public. Instead, through this investment, Ackman’s locking in a price for his investors when UMG lists its shares publicly, which it plans to do later this year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThere’s even more \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-06-04/bill-ackman-s-spac-will-be-three-spacs?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e4D financial chess\u003c/a\u003e going on behind the scenes, but the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/ackmans-spac-deal-to-end-all-spacs-11622818252?mod=hp_featst_pos3\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebottom line\u003c/a\u003e is that shares in Ackman’s SPAC plummeted yesterday following the announcement, meaning investors doubt Ackman can pull off these business theatrics. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: Their moves are a reminder that on some social issues in 2021, companies no longer want to stay neutral.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e Last Sunday, Osaka \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/31/naomi-osaka-highestearning-female-athlete-world-drops-french-open?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edropped out\u003c/a\u003e of the tournament to focus on her mental health after initially declaring she’d skip mandatory press conferences.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOsaka sponsors Sweetgreen, Nike, BareMinerals, and watchmaker Tag Heuer all issued public statements in support of her decision.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eCalm, an app that produces guided meditations, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/calm/status/1400224962544234500?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoffered\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to pay the $15,000 fine for any player opting out of 2021 Grand Slam media appearances for mental health reasons.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt 23, Osaka has earned $55 million in the last 12 months from endorsements, putting her in a tie with Tiger Woods as the twelfth highest-paid athlete in the world. And her outspokenness stands in contrast to many athletes with high-dollar endorsement deals who have stayed quiet in the past. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eBrands want to be seen as taking mental health concerns seriously, and Osaka gives them an opportunity to rally around the cause.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\"
